text: Service Level Agreement (SLA) Policy & Guide
1.0 Document Control

This document outlines the standard Service Level Agreement (SLA) between One2call Limited (the "Service Provider") and its clients (the "Customer"). It is subject to periodic review to ensure it remains aligned with business needs and industry best practices.1 1.1. Version History 3

runs.text: This document outlines the standard Service Level Agreement (SLA) between
(the "Service Provider") and its clients (the "Customer"). It is subject to periodic review to ensure it remains aligned with business needs and industry best practices.

2.0 Agreement Overview
2.1. Introduction

This is a Service Level Agreement (SLA) between [Customer] and One2call Limited. This document identifies the services required and the expected level of service between One2call Limited and the Customer. It serves as the primary tool for managing expectations and creating a shared understanding of responsibilities, timelines, and outcomes.4

runs.text: This is a Service Level Agreement (SLA) between

. This document identifies the services required and the expected level of service between One2call Limited and the Customer. It serves as the primary tool for managing expectations and creating a shared understanding of responsibilities, timelines, and outcomes.

text: 2.2. Purpose
The purpose of this SLA is to specify the requirements of the IT Managed Services provided by One2call Limited with regards to:

runs.text: The purpose of this SLA is to specify the requirements of the IT Managed Services provided by One2call Limited with regards to:

text: A clear and measurable description of the service provision.7

runs.text: A clear and measurable description of the service provision.

text: Agreed-upon service targets for service desk incidents and change requests.

runs.text: Agreed-upon service targets for service desk incidents and change requests.

text: The roles and responsibilities of both One2call Limited and the Customer.

runs.text: The roles and responsibilities of both One2call Limited and the Customer.

text: The procedures for reporting, escalation, and governance.

runs.text: The procedures for reporting, escalation, and governance.

text: The duration, scope, and review cadence of this agreement.

runs.text: The duration, scope, and review cadence of this agreement.

text: 2.3. Scope of Services
This SLA covers the following services provided by One2call Limited:

runs.text: This SLA covers the following services provided by One2call Limited:

text: ● Included Services:
○ Proactive Monitoring and Management
○ Help Desk Support
○ Patch Management
○ Data Backup and Recovery
○ Foundational Cybersecurity (Managed Antivirus, Firewall Management)
○ [List any other specific included services] ● Excluded Services:
○ Support for personal (non-company-owned) devices, unless covered by a premium service tier.

runs.text: Support for personal (non-company-owned) devices, unless covered by a premium service tier.

text: ○ Custom application or software development.
○ [List any other specific excluded services]
3.0 Definitions and Terminology
Term
Definition
SLA
Service Level Agreement: A documented agreement between a service provider and a customer that defines the level of service expected.1

runs.text: Service Level Agreement: A documented agreement between a service provider and a customer that defines the level of service expected.

text: ITIL
Information Technology Infrastructure Library: A globally recognised framework of best practices for IT Service Management.10

runs.text: Information Technology Infrastructure Library: A globally recognised framework of best practices for IT Service Management.

text: Incident
An unplanned interruption to an IT service or reduction in the quality of an IT service.

runs.text: An unplanned interruption to an IT service or reduction in the quality of an IT service.

text: Change
The addition, modification, or removal of anything that could have a direct or indirect effect on IT services.11

runs.text: The addition, modification, or removal of anything that could have a direct or indirect effect on IT services.

text: RFC
Request for Change: A formal proposal for a change to be implemented.11

runs.text: Request for Change: A formal proposal for a change to be implemented.

text: CAB

Change Advisory Board: A group of people that 
supports the assessment, prioritisation, authorisation, and scheduling of changes.11

runs.text: Change Advisory Board: A group of people that
supports the assessment, prioritisation, authorisation, and scheduling of changes.

text: Service Desk Availability
7:00 AM to 7:00 PM, Monday to Friday. Our team is available to take calls, respond to emails, and log tickets during this period.

runs.text: 7:00 AM to 7:00 PM, Monday to Friday.
Our team is available to take calls, respond to emails, and log tickets during this period.

text: SLA Measurement Hours
8:00 AM to 6:00 PM, Monday to Friday, excluding public holidays. All SLA time-based targets (Response and Resolution) are measured within these hours.

runs.text: 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM, Monday to Friday, excluding public holidays.
All SLA time-based targets (Response and Resolution) are measured within these hours.

text: 4.0 Roles and Responsibilities
4.1. One2call Limited Responsibilities
One2call Limited shall:
Provide the services as defined within the scope of this agreement.

runs.text: Provide the services as defined within the scope of this agreement.

text: Meet the response and resolution times as outlined in the service targets.

runs.text: Meet the response and resolution times as outlined in the service targets.

text: Inform the Customer regarding scheduled and unscheduled service outages as necessary.1

runs.text: Inform the Customer regarding scheduled and unscheduled service outages as necessary.

text: Provide regular performance reports and conduct periodic service reviews.4

runs.text: Provide regular performance reports and conduct periodic service reviews.

text: Manage the change process to minimise disruption to the Customer's services.11

runs.text: Manage the change process to minimise disruption to the Customer's services.

text: 4.2. Customer Responsibilities
The Customer shall:
Provide all necessary information and assistance to allow One2call Limited to meet its performance standards.1

runs.text: Provide all necessary information and assistance to allow One2call Limited to meet its performance standards.

text: Inform One2call Limited of any business changes that may impact the services covered by this SLA (e.g., new office locations, significant changes in user count).

runs.text: Inform One2call Limited of any business changes that may impact the services covered by this SLA (e.g., new office locations, significant changes in user count).

text: Ensure its users adhere to company IT policies and procedures. ● Appoint a primary contact for escalations and approvals.

runs.text: Ensure its users adhere to company IT policies and procedures.
Appoint a primary contact for escalations and approvals.

text: 5.0 Service Desk Incident Management SLA
This section defines the commitments for managing and resolving unplanned service interruptions (Incidents).

runs.text: This section defines the commitments for managing and resolving unplanned service interruptions (Incidents).

text: 5.1. The Priority Matrix: Translating Technical Issues into Business Impact

heading.text: 5.1. The Priority Matrix: Translating Technical Issues into Business Impact

runs.text: 5.1. The Priority Matrix: Translating Technical Issues into Business Impact

text: All incidents are categorised using a priority matrix to ensure that issues with the greatest business impact are addressed first.14 Priority is determined by assessing an incident's

runs.text: All incidents are categorised using a priority matrix to ensure that issues with the greatest business impact are addressed first.
Priority is determined by assessing an incident's

text: Impact (the extent of the issue's effect on the business) and Urgency (the speed at which the issue will negatively affect the business).

runs.text: (the extent of the issue's effect on the business) and
(the speed at which the issue will negatively affect the business).

text: Priority Level
Description & Business Impact
Examples
P1 (Critical)
A major business disruption affecting all or a significant majority of users. Business operations are halted.

runs.text: A major business disruption affecting all or a significant majority of users. Business operations are halted.

text: Total network failure, primary server crash, entire organisation unable to send/receive email.

runs.text: Total network failure, primary server crash, entire organisation unable to send/receive email.

text: P2 (High)
A significant business disruption affecting a large group of users or a department. A workaround may exist.

runs.text: A significant business disruption affecting a large group of users or a department. A workaround may exist.

text: CRM system inaccessible to the sales team, departmental file server offline.

runs.text: CRM system inaccessible to the sales team, departmental file server offline.

text: P3 (Medium)
A limited business disruption. An individual user is unable to work effectively, or a non-critical function is failing.

runs.text: A limited business disruption. An individual user is unable to work effectively, or a non-critical function is failing.

text: Single user's computer failing to start, network printer unavailable.

runs.text: Single user's computer failing to start, network printer unavailable.

text: P4 (Low)
Minimal or no business disruption. Minor technical issues or "how-to" questions.

runs.text: Minimal or no business disruption. Minor technical issues or "how-to" questions.

text: Request to change an email signature, question about a software feature.

runs.text: Request to change an email signature, question about a software feature.

text: 5.2. The SLA Clock: Our Key Metrics Defined

heading.text: 5.2. The SLA Clock: Our Key Metrics Defined

runs.text: 5.2. The SLA Clock: Our Key Metrics Defined

text: The journey of a support ticket is measured by three key milestones:

runs.text: The journey of a support ticket is measured by three key milestones:

text: Acknowledgement Time: The time from when a ticket is created to when an automated confirmation is sent to the user. This confirms the request has been logged in our system.15

runs.text: The time from when a ticket is created to when an automated confirmation is sent to the user. This confirms the request has been logged in our system.

text: Response Time (Time to Commence Work): The time from ticket creation until a qualified engineer has reviewed the ticket, confirmed its priority, and begun active work on resolving the issue. This is marked by the first meaningful,

runs.text: The time from ticket creation until a qualified engineer has reviewed the ticket, confirmed its priority, and begun active work on resolving the issue. This is marked by the first meaningful,

text: non-automated communication from the engineer.15
Resolution Time: The total time from ticket creation until the service has been fully restored, confirmed with the user, and the ticket is closed.14

runs.text: The total time from ticket creation until the service has been fully restored, confirmed with the user, and the ticket is closed.

text: SLA Pause Conditions: The SLA clock will be temporarily paused when resolution is dependent on factors outside of our direct control. The clock resumes as soon as the dependency is met. This ensures fair and accurate performance measurement.18 Common pause conditions include:

runs.text: The SLA clock will be temporarily paused when resolution is dependent on factors outside of our direct control. The clock resumes as soon as the dependency is met. This ensures fair and accurate performance measurement.

text: Waiting for a response, information, or testing from the Customer.

runs.text: Waiting for a response, information, or testing from the Customer.

text: Waiting for action from an external third-party vendor (e.g., an ISP or software manufacturer).

runs.text: Waiting for action from an external third-party vendor (e.g., an ISP or software manufacturer).

text: 5.3. Our Service Level Targets for Incidents

heading.text: 5.3. Our Service Level Targets for Incidents

runs.text: 5.3. Our Service Level Targets for Incidents

text: The following table outlines our standard SLA targets for incidents, measured during SLA Measurement Hours (8:00 AM - 6:00 PM, Mon-Fri).

runs.text: The following table outlines our standard SLA targets for incidents, measured during
SLA Measurement Hours (8:00 AM - 6:00 PM, Mon-Fri)

text: Priority Level
Acknowledgement Target (Automated)

Response Target 
(Work Commenced)
Resolution Target
P1 (Critical)
< 5 minutes
< 15-30 minutes
< 4 business hours
P2 (High)
< 15 minutes
< 1-2 business hours
< 8 business hours (1 business day)
P3 (Medium)
< 1 hour
< 4 business hours
< 3 business days
P4 (Low)
< 4 business hours
< 8 business hours (1 business day)
< 5 business days
6.0 Change Management SLA

The primary objective of our Change Management process is to enable beneficial changes to be made with minimum disruption to IT services, governed by the ITIL framework.11 This is achieved through a controlled process of risk assessment, planning, and authorisation.

runs.text: The primary objective of our Change Management process is to enable beneficial changes to be made with minimum disruption to IT services, governed by the ITIL framework.
This is achieved through a controlled process of risk assessment, planning, and authorisation.

text: 6.1. ITIL Change Types
We classify changes into three types to manage risk effectively 20:

runs.text: We classify changes into three types to manage risk effectively

text: Standard Changes: Low-risk, common, pre-authorised changes.
Normal Changes: Changes that require formal review and authorisation before implementation.

runs.text: Changes that require formal review and authorisation before implementation.

text: Emergency Changes: Urgent changes required to resolve a major incident.

runs.text: Urgent changes required to resolve a major incident.

text: 6.2. Standard Changes: Policy and SLA
Definition: Low-risk, frequently performed activities that follow a documented, pre-authorised procedure.20 Because their risk is minimal, they do not require individual CAB approval.

runs.text: Low-risk, frequently performed activities that follow a documented, pre-authorised procedure.
Because their risk is minimal, they do not require individual CAB approval.

text: Examples: Creating a new user account, installing a pre-approved application, replacing a keyboard.

runs.text: Creating a new user account, installing a pre-approved application, replacing a keyboard.

text: SLA Metric: The SLA is based on Fulfilment Time. Requests are typically submitted via our service catalogue.

runs.text: . Requests are typically submitted via our service catalogue.

text: 6.3. Normal Changes: Policy and SLA
Definition: Non-emergency modifications that are not pre-authorised and require a formal Request for Change (RFC) to be submitted for risk assessment and CAB approval.20

runs.text: Non-emergency modifications that are not pre-authorised and require a formal Request for Change (RFC) to be submitted for risk assessment and CAB approval.

text: Examples: Upgrading a core business application, migrating a server, implementing a new firewall.

runs.text: Upgrading a core business application, migrating a server, implementing a new firewall.

text: SLA Metric: The SLA is based on Lead Time. This is the minimum number of days an RFC must be submitted in advance of the planned implementation date to allow for proper planning and risk assessment.

runs.text: . This is the minimum number of days an RFC must be submitted
of the planned implementation date to allow for proper planning and risk assessment.

text: 6.4. Emergency Changes: Policy and SLA
Definition: Changes that must be implemented with extreme urgency to resolve a major incident or remediate a critical security vulnerability.20

runs.text: Changes that must be implemented with extreme urgency to resolve a major incident or remediate a critical security vulnerability.

text: Examples: Applying a patch for a zero-day exploit, restoring a database to resolve a service outage.

runs.text: Applying a patch for a zero-day exploit, restoring a database to resolve a service outage.

text: SLA Metric: The SLA is tied directly to the associated P1 Incident Resolution

runs.text: The SLA is tied directly to the associated

text: Time. The formal process is bypassed for speed, with documentation completed retrospectively.11

runs.text: . The formal process is bypassed for speed, with documentation completed retrospectively.

7.0 Request for Change (RFC) Procedure

For all Normal and Emergency changes, a formal Request for Change (RFC) must be submitted. This ensures all changes are properly documented, assessed for risk, and approved, which is critical for maintaining service stability.13 The RFC should contain the following information:

runs.text: changes, a formal Request for Change (RFC) must be submitted. This ensures all changes are properly documented, assessed for risk, and approved, which is critical for maintaining service stability.
The RFC should contain the following information:

text: Unique ID: A unique identifier for tracking purposes.

runs.text: A unique identifier for tracking purposes.

text: Change Owner: The person responsible for the change project.

runs.text: The person responsible for the change project.

text: Priority: The priority level of the change (e.g., High, Medium, Low).

runs.text: The priority level of the change (e.g., High, Medium, Low).

text: Description of Change: A clear outline of the IT services, software, or hardware that will be changed.

runs.text: A clear outline of the IT services, software, or hardware that will be changed.

text: Reason for Change: The business case and justification for why the change is needed.

runs.text: The business case and justification for why the change is needed.

text: Impact Assessment: The expected positive impacts (e.g., ROI) and potential negative impacts of the change.

runs.text: The expected positive impacts (e.g., ROI) and potential negative impacts of the change.

text: Risk Assessment: An outline of the risks identified (e.g., potential downtime) and the steps taken to mitigate them (e.g., back-out plan, testing).

runs.text: An outline of the risks identified (e.g., potential downtime) and the steps taken to mitigate them (e.g., back-out plan, testing).

text: Planned Implementation Date: The target date for the change.

runs.text: The target date for the change.

text: 8.0 Governance and Review
8.1. Performance Reporting
One2call Limited will provide the Customer with a monthly performance report detailing performance against all SLA metrics.4

runs.text: One2call Limited will provide the Customer with a monthly performance report detailing performance against all SLA metrics.

text: 8.2. Service Reviews

Regular service review meetings, which we refer to as Technical Alignment Meetings (TAMs), will be held to discuss performance, review strategic alignment, and plan for future requirements. 4 For customers on our premium package, this service may be enhanced to include a

runs.text: Regular service review meetings, which we refer to as
, will be held to discuss performance, review strategic alignment, and plan for future requirements.
For customers on our premium package, this service may be enhanced to include a

text: virtual Chief Information Security Officer (vCISO) who provides strategic guidance on cybersecurity and compliance alignment. 24

runs.text: who provides strategic guidance on cybersecurity and compliance alignment.

text: 8.3. SLA Review and Amendment

This SLA is a living document. It will be formally reviewed at least annually, or when significant business changes occur, to ensure it remains relevant and effective.1 Any amendments must be mutually agreed upon by both parties.

runs.text: This SLA is a living document. It will be formally reviewed at least annually, or when significant business changes occur, to ensure it remains relevant and effective.
Any amendments must be mutually agreed upon by both parties.

text: 9.0 Signatories
By signing below, both parties agree to the terms and conditions outlined in this Service Level Agreement.

runs.text: By signing below, both parties agree to the terms and conditions outlined in this Service Level Agreement.
